results.brief_description: This video shows all the offensive skills of volleyball using slow motion replays to clarify every move. A very clear and concise video which should be of help to all volleyball players.

results.title: Individual differences & developmental milestones
results.creator_credit: DLGHS, GPN, George A. Colburn and Darrel Schwandt
results.brief_description:
Episode number 8 of Series “The Worlds of childhood”.
Traces the course of sensorimotor development over the first year. Examines the results of comtemporary research on temperament, auditory and visual acuity, depth perception, phonemic discrimination and cross-modality matching. Presents newborns as they confront situations that allow them to exhibit their capacity to act, learn and remember.

results.title: Individual differences
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Educational Psychology”.
The case study of a shy, slow child, who is different from his classmates and from his older, socially-adept brother, whose reputation is a constant reminder of his own shortcomings. Everyone needs to succeed, the film points out, and most of all those in terms of individual interests and capabilities. It is the job of the school to shape education to these individual needs.

results.title: Indiscretion of an American wife = Stazione Termini
results.creator_credit: Selznick Releasing Organization and Vittorio De Sica
results.brief_description: Mary is an American housewife trying to make the heart-rending decision of whether to go back to her husband and family or remain in Rome with her lover, Giovanni, a university professor she has met during her stay. Most of the story takes place in the Rome railway station, where Mary and Giovanni meet for one last desperate rendezvous. Their search for a secluded spot where they can be together, threatens to expose their illicit affair. However, an understanding railroad commissioner releases the two and Mary is permitted to return to her husband with an unsullied reputation. Cast includes: Jennifer Jones, Montgomery Clift, Gino Cervi and Richard Beymer.

results.title: Indiscreet
results.brief_description: A NATO officer meets a beautiful actress and falls in love with her, but protects himself by saying he is married. The script of this film was written by Norman Krasna, based on his play “Kind Sir”. It stars Cary Grant and Ingrid Bergman.

results.title: Indigenous Voices on the Screen with Professor Gary Foley
results.brief_description: Gumbainggir activist, academic, writer and actor, Professor Gary Foley charts the intersection of Indigenous activism and the world of film and TV in this short film by Yaegl director, producer and storyteller Pauline Clague.

constellations_primary.name: Black Power through film and TV
constellations_primary.description: The Black Power movement of the late 1960s and early 70s was “the most exciting and dynamic era in modern Indigenous history” according to Aboriginal activist Professor Gary Foley, who gained widespread attention for protests during the time and later leveraged film and TV to fight for Indigenous rights.

results.title_for_label: Indigenous Voices on the Screen with Professor Gary Foley
results.description:
Gumbainggir activist, academic, writer and actor, Professor Gary Foley charts the intersection of Indigenous activism and the world of film and TV in this short film by Yaegl director, producer and storyteller Pauline Clague. Through interviews, archival footage and scenes from film and TV, Foley explores the Black Power movement and the period during the 1970s and 80s when First Peoples began taking control of their representation in Australian screen culture, as well as how the moving image has been used to advocate for Indigenous Rights.

“It has been a journey recording Gary about the early years of film. How do you fit the wealth of information into an eight-minute space? I have had the privilege of recording many of the Indigenous trailblazers of the early years of television and film and know how important it is for us to remember those who made a mark on our landscape for us to dream, to make the films and stories we do now. As a person who loves their craft, I hope this gives you a glimpse of the power of our voices on-screen.” – Pauline Clague
description_for_label:
Gumbainggir activist, academic, writer and actor, Professor Gary Foley charts the intersection of Indigenous activism and the world of film and TV in this short film by Yaegl director, producer and storyteller Pauline Clague. Through interviews, archival footage and scenes from film and TV, Foley explores the Black Power movement and the period during the 1970s and 80s when First Peoples began taking control of their representation in Australian screen culture, as well as how the moving image has been used to advocate for Indigenous Rights.

“It has been a journey recording Gary about the early years of film. How do you fit the wealth of information into an eight-minute space? I have had the privilege of recording many of the Indigenous trailblazers of the early years of television and film and know how important it is for us to remember those who made a mark on our landscape for us to dream, to make the films and stories we do now. As a person who loves their craft, I hope this gives you a glimpse of the power of our voices on-screen.” – Pauline Clague

results.title: Indigenous Australians : an Aboriginal community focus
results.brief_description: An interactive CDROM from NSW TAFE which is the first to draw on the comprehensive knowledge and expertise of Aboriginal community members and is an invaluable teaching resource. The concept behind the CD ROM is to let members of various Aboriginal communities become teachers of their rich culture. A resource guide accompanies the CD ROM.
